ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I continued to work on my close reading skills.

I gained a much deeper understanding of the literatures of the Near East, and also of the culture of region as a whole. Crucially, I developed close reading skills, as well as writing skills. This is my first literature seminar, and although it was a bit intimidating at the beginning, I ended up absolutely loving the class. I've never considered myself a writer, but I even ended up writing poetry that I am really proud of!
I learned so much about the middle east and about the history of the region. I also learned a lot about different religions, such as Islam, Christianity, and ancient cultural religions.
I did a lot of close reading.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths:
this close certainly brought me closer to my classmates, many of whom ended up becoming close friends.
Weaknesses:
The level of disorganization was extremely high. The professor failed to provide a definite syllabus by Thanksgiving Break (!) and modified due dates for major assignments up until the week they were due. I normally would appreciate the flexibility, but the poor communication given around deadlines made the situation anxiety-inducing. Secondly, the teachers did not communicate in a timely manner regarding assignments. Although students were expected to hand in first drafts of papers for comments a week or more in advance of the final deadline, comments on drafts were not returned to several students until hours before the final deadline. This failure on the teachers to provide feedback occurred even when students contacted the teachers multiple times. Finally, class discussions often felt superficial. Although I appreciate the importance of reviewing plot elements, there tended to be little substantive discussion of the material. This often led to many class periods consisting of sitting in silence.

Only strengths; this seminar felt like a stream of peace in the midst of the chaotic life at Yale. It was just wonderful to get to spend quality time with 10 other people (who soon became good friends) discussing literature and the culture of the Near East. Professor Slanski is also an extremely caring and brilliant individual.
The major strength of the course is that is it a seminar that is very student directed. Students can have a lot of sway over the discussion and the professor is very open to feedback.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely! This was a wonderful course; I met amazing human beings who became friends, improved my writing and reading skills, and gained a richer understanding of the Near East as a region and of its literature and culture.
I would highly recommend this class to anyone who is interested in learning more about world literature, art, history, and religionthis class has it all.
Yes! really fun and interesting, a great way to try something new and get out of your comfort zone
